column4: okay I'm trying to erase everything and do a fresh install of ubuntu...can I wipe the the entire disk from the live cd?
I mean, like, erase the whole computer windows and everything
just go on manual partitioning if you're using the LiveCD and delete every partition you see.
then setup some partitions for Linux. Generally a / and a /home will do.
danielRM: just to clarify...I run the partitioner from the live cd then restart and click "largest continuous free space"
no, that'll leave everything else you still have on, including Windows and... what, a borked Ubuntu? I assume you had a problem?
that's what I'm going for right now
danielrm, no real problem, it's just windows is a memory hog and it steals space on my hard drive.
then basically just start the LiveCD installer, get through to partitioning, and then choose manual partitioning.
isn't there, like, a program that I can make a boot cd that wipes the drive?
the Ultimate Boot CD has Darik's Boot and Nuke.
which can erase the entire drive.
but it's easier just to wipe the partitions.
danielrm I just ran dban and it "ended with non-fatal errors" basically did nothing. Last time I deleted a hard disk I used window wiper or something I can't remember the name.
odd. If you're using a LiveCD then you could just do this:
dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/<hda/sda/whatever>
danielrm, i'll be honest I don't know what that means. :P
it'll write 0s to the hard drive.
danielrm, am I just typing that into terminal?
as root, yes, but also make sure that you get the right thing for of. of will typically be /dev/hda or /dev/sda; the latter is more common for laptops, the former for desktops.
ok thanks for the advice guys, I'm off to experiment, everythings backed up already, so no worries
OK. Good luck.
